entry.title: Quadtree partitioning
entry.summary: High resolution data can pose problems in memory requirements, expecially in higher dimensions. We explore a simple way of reducing a 2d array by clustering together neighbouring elements that are within a given standard deviation. The function recursively groups together data points until the standard deviation cirteria is not satisfied â€¦
entry.content:
High resolution data can pose problems in memory requirements, expecially in higher dimensions. We explore a simple way of reducing a 2d array by clustering together neighbouring elements that are within a given standard deviation. The function recursively groups together data points until the standard deviation cirteria is not satisfied anymore. The resulting data structure is also known as a Quadtree.

In [2]:
def divide(data, x_low, x_high, y_low, y_high, std):
    '''Divide 2d array up such that the standard deviaiton is < std
    
    Paramters
    ---------
    data : 2d-array
    x_low x_high, y_low, y_high: int
    std : float
    '''
    if np.std(data[x_low:x_high, y_low:y_high]) < std:
        return np.mean(data[x_low:x_high, y_low:y_high])

    x_middle = x_low + (x_high - x_low) // 2
    y_middle = y_low + (y_high - y_low) // 2
    
    return [divide(data, x_low, x_middle, y_low, y_middle, std),
            divide(data, x_middle, x_high, y_low, y_middle, std),
            divide(data, x_low, x_middle, y_middle, y_high, std),
            divide(data, x_middle, x_high, y_middle, y_high, std)]

To illustrate it we generate a 1024x1024 image

In [3]:
N = 1024
x = np.cos(np.linspace(0, 2*np.pi, N))
y = np.cos(np.linspace(0, 2*np.pi, N))
test_data = np.outer(x,y)

fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(6,6))
ax.imshow(test_data)
ax.set_title('Original');
In [4]:
partition = divide(test_data, 0, N, 0, N, 0.01)

The result is a nested list, and each element has four entries,

[[child1, child2, child3, child4], ...]

or in case of a leafe it is the resulting number as a float.

In order to reconstruct the original image from this quadtree format, we define a helper function.

In [ ]:
def lookup(partition, x, y, x_low, x_high, y_low, y_high):
    '''Lookup value in partitioned data at position x and y
    '''
    if not isinstance(partition, list):
        return partition
    
    x_middle = x_low + (x_high - x_low) // 2
    y_middle = y_low + (y_high - y_low) // 2
    
    lx = x >= x_middle
    ly = y >= y_middle
    
    if ly:
        if lx:
            return lookup(partition[3], x, y, x_middle, x_high, y_middle, y_high)
        return lookup(partition[2], x, y, x_low, x_middle, y_middle, y_high)
    if lx:
        return lookup(partition[1], x, y, x_middle, x_high, y_low, y_middle)
    return lookup(partition[0], x, y, x_low, x_middle, y_low, y_middle)
In [ ]:
reconstructed_img = np.empty((N,N))

for x in range(N):
    for y in range(N):
        reconstructed_img[x,y] = lookup(partition, x, y, 0, N, 0, N)
        
fig, ax = plt.subplots(1,2, figsize=(20,8))

im = ax[0].imshow(reconstructed_img)
ax[0].set_title('Recosntructed Image')
plt.colorbar(im, ax=ax[0])

im = ax[1].imshow(reconstructed_img-test_data, cmap='RdBu')
ax[1].set_title('Error')
plt.colorbar(im, ax=ax[1]);

So what is the comprression that we achieved?¶

To accurately compter the size of the full object, I use this function. In this example the nested list has a size of 30% of the original data.

In [ ]:
size_compressed = get_size(partition)
size_original = get_size(test_data)
print('%.2f'%(size_compressed / size_original))
